dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 1,450 point drop for the Dow, that's a brutal Friday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A fourteen fifty point drop for the Dow, that's a brutal Friday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.2%, over 1,400 points, by mid-afternoon on Thursday, while the S&P 500 was down 4.2% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 3.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the S&P 500 turning negative for the year after that brief moment of hope? Oof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the S&P five hundred turning negative for the year after that brief moment of hope? Oof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of losses, turning negative for the year after briefly turning positive for 2020 earlier this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's all about the Fed's warning, right? They're not even thinking about raising rates until like, 2022.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all about the Fed's warning, right? They're not even thinking about raising rates until like, twenty twenty two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Fed concluded its two-day meeting on Wednesday by leaving interest rates unchanged near zero and indicating that they will stay there until 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Jerome Powell basically said they'll do whatever it takes, but the forecast is just... grim.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Jerome Powell basically said they'll do whatever it takes, but the forecast is just... grim.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He added that while there is great uncertainty about the future, the Fed is strongly committed to doing whatever we can, for as long as it takes to help support the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got Florida, um, reporting record hospitalizations after reopening early. That second wave fear is real.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got Florida, um, reporting record hospitalizations after reopening early. That second wave fear is real.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wall Street is increasingly worried about a second wave of coronavirus infections: Texas, for example, was one of the first states to reopen, but recently reported three consecutive days of record hospitalizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. All those stocks that were rallying on reopen optimism—airlines, cruises—they got hammered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. All those stocks that were rallying on reopen optimism-airlines, cruises-they got hammered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks that would benefit from a reopeningincluding airlines, retailers and cruise operatorshave all plunged recently, after having led the market rally in the past few weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, tech is having a moment again. The Nasdaq actually hit 10,000 this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, tech is having a moment again. The Nasdaq actually hit ten thousand this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That helped the Nasdaq hit a new record high on Wednesday, when it closed above 10,000 for the first time ever.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, Amazon, Netflix, all those giants are propping things up while everything else sinks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, Amazon, Netflix, all those giants are propping things up while everything else sinks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet have all been soaring recently, boosting the index higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet, another 1.6 million jobless claims this week. We're at over 44 million unemployed in three months.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet, another one point six million jobless claims this week. We're at over forty four million unemployed in three months.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weekly jobless claims fell for the tenth week in a row on Thursday, with 1.5 million more Americans filing for unemployment during the week ending June 6.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's just a stark reminder the market isn't the economy. The recovery's gonna take years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just a stark reminder the market isn't the economy. The recovery's gonna take years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While that number continues to decline, millions remain unemployed and the job markets recovery is expected to take years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So investors are caught between Fed support and pure panic about cases spiking again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So investors are caught between Fed support and pure panic about cases spiking again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. This volatility is not going away anytime soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. This volatility is not going away anytime soon.
